Award.AwardTitle: STTR Phase I: An augmentative tool to connect speech language pathologists with patients
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Technology Transfer (STTR) Phase I project addresses the issue of communicative ability in individuals with neurogenic disorders. The inability to engage in spoken communication is among the most debilitating of all human conditions. Because treatment is behavioral and intensive, access to care and quality of care are significant issues. These are problems that disproportionately affect those in rural and underserved areas, leaving them with a persistent communication deficit. The clinical implications of the tools proposed here are considerable. The analytical approach summarized in this proposal should both improve the performance of individual speech and language pathologists while also enabling them to serve many more patients. Such a tool could be deployed to individuals with increased risk of Parkinson?s, Alzheimer?s, or other related neurological disorders that impact speech production.

The proposed project addresses these issues through a tool that allows patients to remotely record speech and video samples and provides a variety of derived calculations, novel and traditional, to assess the integrity of speech. This approach provides access to expertise in rural areas with the goal of reducing health disparities in the field. The approach makes use of recent technical advances in the emerging field of personalized telemedicine, in conjunction with the increasingly widespread use of tablets in clinical practice, to remotely track abnormal speech production in at-risk individuals and augment human perceptual evaluation through modern data analytics. Realizing this vision requires the development of an advanced signal processing methodology and a suite of mobile applications that implements it in scalable fashion.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The mission of Aural Analytics is to significantly improve treatment access for underserved communities by providing automatic evaluation and intervention in speech therapy. Our proprietary technology algorithmically evaluates a speech signal along a number of perceptual dimensions that have been shown to contribute to decreased intelligibility and produces a set of objective outcome measures that allow speech-language pathologists (SLPs) to make data-informed decisions about the initiation, continuation, adaptation or termination of a given treatment protocol. The objective of our 18 month STTR project was to mature, validate, implement and begin to commercialize this technology. Our twelve-month Phase I project specifically focused on refining a telemedicine application that was originally developed with the goal of allowing clinicians to remotely conduct speech therapy with their patients in an automated manner. Our six-month Phase IB project used the developed Phase I mobile technology to implement an on-line tool for SLP practice and training.

 

Program Outcome: Intellectual Merit

Algorithm Development: A principal outcome of our research was the development of a computational engine that we call Automatic Ratings for Intelligibility Assessment or ARIA. The ARIA engine takes as an input a set of speech samples from a speaker with dysarthria, extracts acoustic features from the speech signal, and automatically evaluates the speech along five perceptual dimensions on a scale from 1 [normal] to 7 [severely abnormal]. The ARIA computational engine was the basis for both applications.

 

Algorithm Evaluation: We compared the performance of the ARIA engine relative existing approach that is based on the SLP judgement. Developing a meaningful performance metric is critical and very much a function of the particular application. We decided to measure the relative performance through the mean absolute error and the correlation coefficient between the ratings provided by the user and the algorithmic ratings. That is, the clinician was presented with a series of a speech samples from our proprietary database, listened to the sample and provided their ratings. These ratings were scored against the algorithmic results, which are taken to be the gold standard of performance. The ARIA engine was shown to perform as predicted.

 

Application Development: The ARIA engine was integrated in within a mobile application framework to evaluate it potential in tele-healthcare. Two particular applications were demonstrated during our STTR program: (i) Speaklear was implemented in Phase I; and (ii) the SLP Practice / Training Tool was implemented during Phase IB. We note that the SLP Practice / Training Tool currently exists as a web-based tool, but because it is written in HTML5 it is easily ported to mobile platforms.

 

Broader Impact:

We identified the ability of connecting speech therapists with clients that previously had no access to their services and ensuring continuity of care for existing patients as critical societal needs. We demonstrated that ARIA engine can augment current care provided by SLPs. We demonstrated that the ARIA engine can be implemented in on both mobile platforms and as a web-based tool. These results demonstrated the potential for increasing access to quality speech care and reducing disparities in healthcare outcomes.  We demonstrated the viability of Software as a service (SaaS) as a general revenue more for distributing our technology.
